title: U.K. launches security probe into U.S. buyout group Advent’s £4 billion Cobham takeover
text:
The U.K. government has ordered an investigation into the £4 billion acquisition of defense manufacturer Cobham COB, -0.47% by U.S. private equity firm Advent International on national security grounds.

The move comes just two days after Advent received overwhelming shareholder approval for the deal to acquire one of U.K.’s oldest aerospace and defense companies.

Andrea Leadsom, secretary of state for business, energy and industrial strategy, said the intervention notice was issued after “careful consideration”. She said: “The government’s goals are to support private sector innovation whilst safeguarding the public interest.”

Ministers are coming under pressure to protect British companies in the wake of a series of takeovers by foreign bidders and opposition parties welcomed Leadsom’s move.

Richard Tice, chair of the Brexit Party, told MarketWatch: “We are delighted that the government is intervening in this vital national strategic defense asset.”

Stephanie Peacock, Labour MP for Barnsley East, said: “This is an important U.K. company with hundreds of British workers in a specialized industry and a supply chain that provides many more across the country.”

She added: “Ministers have referred this deal to the CMA [Competition and Markets Authority] on security grounds, but it should not be agreed without a binding guarantee that those jobs won’t be lost or outsourced.”

Cobham employs 10,000 people, including 1,700 in the U.K.

The CMA will investigate the transaction and review its national security implications. It has until midnight on October 29 to complete and submit the report to the secretary of state.

Russ Mould, an investment director at retail stockbroker AJ Bell, said a muted stock-price reaction — Cobham shares were down 0.6% to 159.6p in lunchtime trading in London — suggested that “rightly or wrongly, the market expects the deal to go through”.

An Advent spokesperson said: “Advent is committed to being a responsible steward of Cobham, encouraging its future growth and success. We will continue to engage constructively and cooperatively with the U.K. government in this part of their review.”

The move by Leadsom also follows weeks of controversy surrounding the acquisition. Last month, Nadine Cobham — who was married to former boss Michael Cobham — wrote to defense secretary Ben Wallace asking him to intervene in the deal. She said Advent’s purchase posed a threat to the UK’s manufacturing capabilities and valuable high-tech jobs.

Both Cobham and Advent have claimed the takeover doesn’t have any national security implications.

This is the second time the government has involved itself in a buyout in the last three months. In July, the former secretary of state for digital, culture, media and sport, Jeremy Wright, issued a public interest intervention notice, launching a probe into the acquisition of U.K. satellite group Inmarsat ISAT, +0.00% by a private equity-led consortium on national security grounds.

The $3.4 billion bid by Apax, Warburg Pincus, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan Board was initially announced in March.

Since 2003, there have only been 12 public-interest interventions, seven of which were on national security grounds, according to U.K. government data. There hasn’t yet been a transaction that was prohibited following such intervention.
